title: PPLE Skills and Research Methods for Psychology: tutorial manual
text:
Preface
Welcome! In these pages you will find tutorial materials for the PPLE Skills and Research Methods for Psychology JASP tutorials. For questions, please get in touch!

title: 2  Introduction
text:
This is a book created from markdown and executable code.
See Knuth (1984) for additional discussion of literate programming.

1 + 1

[1] 2






Knuth, Donald E. 1984. “Literate Programming.” Comput. J. 27 (2): 97–111. https://doi.org/10.1093/comjnl/27.2.97.

title: 2  Summary
text:
In summary, this book has no content whatsoever.

1 + 1

[1] 2

title: 1  Data wrangling and visualization in JASP
text:
1.1 Learning outcomes
After viewing the tutorial materials and following along with the demonstration, you can:
crumbs: 1  Data wrangling and visualization in JASP

title: 1  Data wrangling and visualization in JASP
text:
Filter data according to certain values of cases (select cases)
Compute new variables from existing variables
Recode existing variables into new variables
Run descriptive statistics and frequencies
crumbs: 1  Data wrangling and visualization in JASP

title: 1  Data wrangling and visualization in JASP
text:
1.2 Datasets
This demonstration uses the dataset ReducedESS11 which is based on the ESS11 dataset (Norwegian Agency for Shared Services in Education & Research, 2025). You can download it here.
The dataset consists of 7 variables:

Country

Belgium, France, Germany, Hungary and the Netherlands

imsmetn (“Allow many/few immigrants of same race/ethnic group as majority”)

“Allow none”
“Allow some”
“Allow a few”
“Allow none”

imdfetn (“Allow many/few immigrants of different race/ethnic group from majority”)

Scale as imsmetn

impcntr (“Allow many/few immigrants from poorer countries outside Europe”)

Scale as imsmetn

imbgeco (“Immigration bad or good for country’s economy”)

Scale from 0 (“Bad for the economy”) to 10 (“Good for the economy”)

imueclt (“Country’s cultural life undermined or enriched by immigrants”)

Scale from 0 (“Cultural life undermined”) to 10 (“Cultural life enriched”)

imwbcnt (“Immigrants make country worse or better place to live”)

Scale from 0 (“Worse place to live”) to 10 (“Better place to live”)
crumbs: 1  Data wrangling and visualization in JASP

text:

Check the assumptions of normality and homogeneity of variances, using plots and tests

This demonstration uses the dataset ReducedESS11 which you can download here. You can see a summary of the variables in the previous tutorial.

title: 3  Bias and checking assumptions
text:
3.4 Reporting

3.4.1 t-tests

t(degrees of freedom) = t-value, p = p-value, d = cohen’s d



3.4.2 ANOVA

F(numerator/effect degrees of freedom, denominator/residual degrees of freedom) = F-value, p = p-value, \(\omega^2\) = omega-squared value



3.4.3 \(\chi^2\)

\(\chi^2\)(n, degrees of freedom) = chi-squared value, p = p-value, V = Cramer’s V value

title: 3  t-tests, one-way ANOVA and \(\chi^2\) tests of independence
text:
3.4 Reporting

3.4.1 t-tests

t(degrees of freedom) = t-value, p = p-value, d = cohen’s d



3.4.2 ANOVA

F(numerator/effect degrees of freedom, denominator/residual degrees of freedom) = F-value, p = p-value, \(\omega^2\) = omega-squared value



3.4.3 \(\chi^2\)

\(\chi^2\)(n, degrees of freedom) = chi-squared value, p = p-value, V = Cramer’s V value
crumbs: 3  t-tests, one-way ANOVA and $\chi^2$ tests of independence

title: Appendix A — APA reporting style for statistical tests
text:
A.3 ANOVA

F(numerator/effect degrees of freedom, denominator/residual degrees of freedom) = F-value, p = p-value, \(\omega^2\) = omega-squared value
crumbs: A  APA reporting style for statistical tests

title: Appendix A — APA reporting style for statistical tests
text:
A.4 \(\chi^2\)

\(\chi^2\)(n, degrees of freedom) = chi-squared value, p = p-value, V = Cramer’s V value
crumbs: A  APA reporting style for statistical tests

title: Appendix A — APA reporting style for statistical tests
text:
A.5 Regression

Coefficients: b = coefficient/slope value, t(degrees of freedom) = t-value, p = p-value
With many coefficients, a table can be more efficient


A.5.1 Mediation

Coefficients and tests for different paths can be reported as for standard regression
if using bootstrapped and bias-corrected confidence intervals (e.g., as produced when using PROCESS), then: b = coefficient/path value, 95% BCa CI = [CI lower bound, CI upper bound]



A.5.2 Moderation

Coefficients and tests (including those from simple slopes analyses) can be reported as for standard regression
With many coefficients, a table can be more efficient
crumbs: A  APA reporting style for statistical tests

title: Appendix B — The impact of assumption violations on test results
text:
B.2 Homogeneity of variances

B.2.1 Type-I error rate (\(\alpha\))









False positive rate for:

Equal variances and equal n = 0.049
Unequal variances and equal n = 0.049
Unequal variances and unequal n = 0.057



B.2.2 Power (1 - \(\beta\))
crumbs: B  The impact of assumption violations on test results
